title.#text: Making a killing: photographic evidence of predation of a Tasmanian pademelon () by a feral cat ()

author.details: School of Biological Sciences, University of Tasmania, Private Bag 55, Hobart, Tas. 7001, Australia. Email:

front.abstract: Feral cats (Felis catus) have contributed to the extinction of numerous Australian mammals and are a major threat to many species of conservation significance. Small mammals are considered to be those at greatest risk of cat predation, with risk typically inferred from dietary studies. However, dietary studies may provide only weak inference as to the risk of cat predation for some species. The most compelling evidence of predation risk comes from direct observation of killing events; however, such observations are rare and photographic evidence is even rarer. I present photographic evidence of a feral cat killing and consuming an adult female Tasmanian pademelon (Thylogale billardierii). This observation provides direct evidence that feral cats can kill prey up to 4kg in body mass, with potential implications for the conservation of medium-sized mammals.
front.keywords: diet, prey, red-bellied pademelon, rufous-bellied pademelon.
